ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a combination of live virtual discussions, reading outside of class and bi-weekly blog posts.
We met twice a week on zoom in a small seminar format.
None

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read and analyse poetry at a speed and depth that I had never done before.
You learn a lot about the classics of poetry. As there is also a lot of writing, I became a much better writer.
I developed skills in closer reading, group discussion, writing, synthesizing ideas, and deeper thinking.

Taking this course as a first-year helped me transition from writing at the high school level to writing college-level papers. I learned how to fashion a new, nuanced argument about a text and picked up new techniques for how to craft those ideas into an engaging paper. Our class discussions also helped me improve my close-reading skills.

English 125 brought a cohesive introduction and sampling of Medieval poetry beginning with Beowulf and ending at Milton's Paradise Lost. We then used many of our insights gained from each of these works read in class and applied them to the real modern world, suggesting that older poetry still plays a quintessential role in our current lives.
I improved on analyzing texts, specifically English poetry. I better understand how to write an essay as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that this course was fantastic. I loved all of the works that we read and I thought that it had a perfect reading to class ration.

This course helped shape me into a better writer and thinker. Occasionally we would cover a lot of material between classes but only spend time on one very small component, and it would have been easier to develop more complex thoughts on the singular component if there wasn't as much content.

This is an excellent course; we read some incredible works of literature, and our class discussions and writing assignments helped me glean more from the texts than I would have if I had simply read them on my own. Professor Ulrich struck the perfect balance between pointing us to interested parts of the text and letting us discuss our own thoughts. She gave us some excellent tips about writing our papers towards the middle of the term and had us workshop a few paragraphs from our essays. Since this was so helpful, I would have appreciate it if this had come at the beginning of the term; it would have helped me improve the quality of my first few essays.

The numerous essays really got me back into shape in terms of writing. In terms of improvement, (this is a personal problem) perhaps a dedicated class to reading deeper? I think reading deeper and finding interesting ideas to talk about was one of my greatest problems in this class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that this class was super engaging. It was definitely the best course that I had this semester in terms of being engaging during online learning.
This course was as successful during COVID-19 as it could have been.

The blog posts we wrote after each reading assignment helped keep me engaged with all the texts we read. Professor Ulrich did an excellent job of gauging what interested the class based on these posts and tailoring our seminar to address many of these points. Our seminar was small enough that discussions flowed very smoothly over Zoom.
I really liked the seminar style Zoom sessions. In terms of improvement, nothing comes to mind.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! This was one of the best courses that I have taken at Yale so far. Professor Ulrich is such an engaging teacher and she really got me excited about the material.

Yes. But only if you are 1) interested in the subject matter and 2) up for a lot of work. There was a lot of writing and the grading was very difficult. Don't take this if you are looking for an easy writing credit. However, if you are interested in the subject matter definitely take it as Professor Ulrich is extremely knowledgable and sheds new light on all the texts. She will also make you a much better writer.
Yes! This course will challenge your mind and requires a lot of work and attention, but you will reap the benefits of a great learning experience and enjoyable class discussions.

Definitely! You get to discuss some absolutely beautiful works of literature with students who are just as interested in them as you are. I particularly recommend taking this course with Professor Ulrich. She made sure that every single discussion we had was productive and engaging; she'll work with you on your essay topics if you go to her for office hours, and she'll give you plenty of helpful feedback on your writing.
I would if they were interested in poetry. I would warn them of the essays though since, from what I've heard, this class has longer essays compared to other first-year English classes.
